hints.content: Start by understanding what a 'fair integer' is. A fair integer is defined as an integer that has the same number of digits as the given integer and is composed of digits that are all the same. For example, 222 and 444 are fair integers.

Consider how to generate fair integers. You can generate fair integers by repeating a single digit from 1 to 9 for the length of the input integer. For instance, for a 2-digit integer, you can generate 11, 22, 33, ..., 99.
Think about how to find the closest fair integer to the given integer. You will need to compare the generated fair integers with the input integer and determine which one is closest.

When comparing distances, remember to consider both the absolute difference and the possibility of ties. If two fair integers are equally close to the input integer, you should return the smaller one.
Make sure to handle edge cases, such as when the input integer is already a fair integer. In such cases, the closest fair integer is the integer itself.
To efficiently find the closest fair integer, you might want to store the generated fair integers in a list. This way, you can iterate through them to find the closest one.
Consider the maximum and minimum possible fair integers based on the length of the input integer. For example, if the input is 403 (3 digits), the fair integers range from 111 to 999.

When calculating the closest fair integer, ensure your logic accounts for all possible fair integers of the same length as the input integer. You might want to create a loop that generates these integers.
As you implement the comparison logic, remember to use the absolute value function to find the distance. For example: `distance = abs(fair_integer - input_integer)`.

Finally, as you finalize your solution, ensure that you return the closest fair integer in the required format. If you have a tie, return the smaller integer. This will ensure your solution meets all problem requirements.

Fair integers consist of repeated digits (e.g., 111, 222).
In case of ties, return the smaller integer.
Consider edge cases where the input is already a fair integer.
